article.title: Effects of angular frequency during clinorotation on mesenchymal stem cell morphology and migration

funding.text: National Aeronautics and Space Administration Space Biology Program
funding.label: Grant

article.abstract: To determine the short-term effects of simulated microgravity on mesenchymal stem cell behaviors—as a function of clinorotation speed—using time-lapse microscopy.

sections.introduction: Intricate multi-scale interactions among cells, tissues, and organs fundamentally govern human health, which has evolved on Earth under a constant gravitational load of 1 g (9.8 m/s2). The biological mechanisms underlying the role of gravity in human health remain poorly understood, but their elucidation is necessary for enabling long-term manned space exploration.
sections.methods: hMSCs were obtained from a commercial source (PT-2501, Lonza, Walkersville, MD, USA), and confirmed to be mycoplasma-free.
sections.results: Simulated microgravity had a profound effect on both the extent and kinetics of cell spreading (Figure 2).
sections.discussion: Understanding how angular frequency, or rotation speed, of clinorotation affects cell behavior is a critical aspect of microgravity simulation experiments,

article.insights_summary: This study investigated the effects of clinorotation speed on the morphology, cytoarchitecture, and migration behavior of human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs). The results showed that hMSCs respond to clinorotation by adopting more rounded, less-spread morphologies, and that the angular frequency-dependence suggests that a cell's ability to sense the changing gravity vector is governed by the...
article.acknowledgments: This work was supported by National Aeronautics and Space Administration Space Biology Program, Grant NNX13AM06G.
